First they visited the Physiology
building. With Mr. Coy as the
guide, the various lecture rooms and
laboratories were inspected. The
Pharmacology labs were of especial interest and Dr. Lamsen, of the
Pharmacological staff, was very
kind in demonstrating an experiment on which he was working.
The apparatus for this experiment
involved the setting up of an artificial system of blood circulation.
The mechanism was so perfect that
the beat of a human heart and the
throb of a human pulse were reproduced to the minutest detail. Absolute control of the rate of the
beat, the strength of the beat, and
the volume of the blood passing
through the veins, was demonstrated. Another interesting experiment viewed in the Physiology
building was the test for the absorption of carbon tetra-chloride,
a substance administered for the
cure of the hookworm disease.
Enter Storage Room of "Stiffs"

After leaving the Physiology
building the Anatomy building was
viewed. Here Mr. Coy turned the
group oved to Dr. Langworthy,
who conducted them through the
dissecting rooms, lecture rooms and
Ice-box. It was rather gruesome
but very interesting to see the
Chamber where one hundred and
fifty cadavres, or "stiffs," as they
call them at the med. school, are
stored away, hanging on pulleys like
meat in a refrigerator. Dr. Langworthy said that the ice-box was
the best in the country. He also
told that the stiffs were kept sometimes five years after coming from
the morgue or poorhouse. Of
course, only unclaimed bodies are
used for dissecting purposes, and
even then they must be stored for
clue year to await claiming. The
Pulley system for moving the bodles is very convenient, since it does
away with handling them by hand
to a great extent.
From the Anatomy building the
Party proceeded to the Pathology
building, a new, modern eight-story
structure on the southwest corner
of Wolfe and Monument Streets.

The above is a facsimile of an original letter written by Woodrow Wilson about his diploma in 1886 to Mr. Thomas R. Ball, then
registrar of the University. This is one of the three documents by
Wilson recently found in the registrar's office.

DISCOVERY OF WOODROW WILSON'S LETTERS
RECALLS GREAT PRESIDENT'S STUDENT DAYS
One Letter Tells of Diploma Withheld for Thirty-cent Payment. Wilson Was
Active in Non-athletic Activities When at University.
Returned as Lecturer for Ten Years

Two letters and an application
blank, unearthed last Wednesday
from the obscurity of a dust-covered file in the Registrar's Office,
furnish a glimpse of Woodrow Wilson's student days at Johns Hopkins University.
One of the two letters is a note
to Mr. Thomas R. Ball, then Registrar of the University, enclosing
thirty cents which stood between
Wilson and a diploma. It is written on a sheet of paper from a
writing tablet and is dated 1886.
The other letter is dated 1883
and i a request for information
concerning entrance requirements.
It is a simple note addressed to Dr.
Gilman, the first President of Johns
Hopkins, and asks, in a businesslike manner, for the academic and
financial qualifications needed for
entrance.
The application, filed soon after
the letter asking for information
was written, states that Woodrow
Wilson's previous education consisted of one year spent at Davidson College, South Carolina; foui
years' residence at Princeton, culminating in 1879, when he receivea
his Degree of Bachelor of Arts:
and one year and three months
study at the University. of Virginia, where he took the Degr2e of
Doctor of Laws. His age, as given
at the time, was twenty-seven.
On entering Johns Hopkins
Woodrow Wilson, according to
other records, wished to study Political Science, General History and
Constitutional History. He had,

during the course of his studies at
Davidson, Princeton, and Virginia,
taken many other subjects of the
same character, such as The Constitutional Machinery of the English Government, Colonial History,
Free Trade, and Controversy upon
General Political Economy.
During his two years' residence
at Johns Hopkins, which were separated by a year of ill-health, Woodrow Wilson was active in non-athContinued on page 4 col. 2

the Honor System.
Honor is impelled upon every person, not by some external force,
but by the inner requisites of morality and truth. Honor is ethically
indispensable. The Honor System, therefore, is a moral obligation, and
as such, is not subject to addition or subtraction.
The Honor System not only assumes that every man at Johns
Hopkins is a gentleman and will conduct himself as such under all circumstances, but it also presupposes that, in addition to observing its
rules, each student will take sufficient pride in the personnel of his Alma
Mater to report any infringement upon it which he may observe. Failure to report any known violation of the Honor System constitutes a
breach as serious as the violation itself.
Johns Hopkins was among the first to adopt such a system, and
at our University the Honor System has established for itself a unique
and enviable record. It is one of Hopkins' most cherished traditions.
The success of the Honor System remains at all times in the hands of

See Artificial Blood System

First they visited the Physiology
building. With Mr. Coy as the
guide, the various lecture rooms and
laboratories were inspected. The
Pharmacology labs were of especial interest and Dr. Lamsen, of the
Pharmacological staff, was very
kind in demonstrating an experiment on which he was working.
The apparatus for this experiment
involved the setting up of an artificial system of blood circulation.
The mechanism was so perfect that
the beat of a human heart and the
throb of a human pulse were reproduced to the minutest detail. Absolute control of the rate of the
beat, the strength of the beat, and
the volume of the blood passing
through the veins, was demonstrated. Another interesting experiment viewed in the Physiology
building was the test for the absorption of carbon tetra-chloride,
a substance administered for the
cure of the hookworm disease.
Enter Storage Room of "Stiffs"

After leaving the Physiology
building the Anatomy building was
viewed. Here Mr. Coy turned the
group oved to Dr. Langworthy,
who conducted them through the
dissecting rooms, lecture rooms and
Ice-box. It was rather gruesome
but very interesting to see the
Chamber where one hundred and
fifty cadavres, or "stiffs," as they
call them at the med. school, are
stored away, hanging on pulleys like
meat in a refrigerator. Dr. Langworthy said that the ice-box was
the best in the country. He also
told that the stiffs were kept sometimes five years after coming from
the morgue or poorhouse. Of
course, only unclaimed bodies are
used for dissecting purposes, and
even then they must be stored for
clue year to await claiming. The
Pulley system for moving the bodles is very convenient, since it does
away with handling them by hand
to a great extent.
From the Anatomy building the
Party proceeded to the Pathology
building, a new, modern eight-story
structure on the southwest corner
of Wolfe and Monument Streets.

DISCOVERY OF WOODROW WILSON'S LETTERS
RECALLS GREAT PRESIDENT'S STUDENT DAYS
One Letter Tells of Diploma Withheld for Thirty-cent Payment. Wilson Was
Active in Non-athletic Activities When at University.
Returned as Lecturer for Ten Years

Two letters and an application
blank, unearthed last Wednesday
from the obscurity of a dust-covered file in the Registrar's Office,
furnish a glimpse of Woodrow Wilson's student days at Johns Hopkins University.
One of the two letters is a note
to Mr. Thomas R. Ball, then Registrar of the University, enclosing
thirty cents which stood between
Wilson and a diploma. It is written on a sheet of paper from a
writing tablet and is dated 1886.
The other letter is dated 1883
and i a request for information
concerning entrance requirements.
It is a simple note addressed to Dr.
Gilman, the first President of Johns
Hopkins, and asks, in a businesslike manner, for the academic and
financial qualifications needed for
entrance.
The application, filed soon after
the letter asking for information
was written, states that Woodrow
Wilson's previous education consisted of one year spent at Davidson College, South Carolina; foui
years' residence at Princeton, culminating in 1879, when he receivea
his Degree of Bachelor of Arts:
and one year and three months
study at the University. of Virginia, where he took the Degr2e of
Doctor of Laws. His age, as given
at the time, was twenty-seven.
On entering Johns Hopkins
Woodrow Wilson, according to
other records, wished to study Political Science, General History and
Constitutional History. He had,

during the course of his studies at
Davidson, Princeton, and Virginia,
taken many other subjects of the
same character, such as The Constitutional Machinery of the English Government, Colonial History,
Free Trade, and Controversy upon
General Political Economy.
During his two years' residence
at Johns Hopkins, which were separated by a year of ill-health, Woodrow Wilson was active in non-athContinued on page 4 col. 2
letic activities of the University.

the Honor System.
Honor is impelled upon every person, not by some external force,
but by the inner requisites of morality and truth. Honor is ethically
indispensable. The Honor System, therefore, is a moral obligation, and
as such, is not subject to addition or subtraction.
The Honor System not only assumes that every man at Johns
Hopkins is a gentleman and will conduct himself as such under all circumstances, but it also presupposes that, in addition to observing its
rules, each student will take sufficient pride in the personnel of his Alma
Mater to report any infringement upon it which he may observe. Failure to report any known violation of the Honor System constitutes a
breach as serious as the violation itself.
Johns Hopkins was among the first to adopt such a system, and
at our University the Honor System has established for itself a unique
and enviable record. It is one of Hopkins' most cherished traditions.

The hair is the most

Smooth, well-kept hair

is now so easy to have!
NKEMPT hair was once as
nearly universal as smooth,
neatly-combed hair is today.
Of course, well-dressed men
realized then as well as now that
nothing spoils the whole appearance so quickly as hair that is out
of place.
But what could they do?
, Old-fashioned pomades only
matted the hair and made it
greasy. Water evaporated within
an hour and left the hair drier and
more unruly than ever. There
wasn't a thing that could keep
the hair smoothly in place from
morning till night—natural, soft,
lustrous.
That's why Stacomb was introduced. .

U

At last—a way to keep
the hair in place
At first known only in California
colleges, the story of Stacomb
quickly spread. Today, welldressed men everywhere have
found in Stacomb what they have

r1

always needed—an easy, natural
way to keep the hair looking just
as they want it to look at all
times.
Perhaps you part your hair in
the middle. Perhaps on the right
side. Perhaps on the left. Perhaps you comb it straight back.
It makes no difference; Stacomb
will keep it just the way you like
it best. A touch of it in the morning, and your hair will stay just
the way you want it all day long.
No matter how uncontrollable
your hair may be after being
washed—no matter how dry and
straggly by nature—Stacomb will
keep it in perfect order, always
smooth, trim, lustrous.
Women use Stacomb, too. They
find it excellent to control stray
hairs, to make the curl stay in, and
to keep the hair severely close to the
head in the prevailing fashion.
Use Stacomb tomorrow morning,
